facts.text: Asa Ram is the appellant and runs certain machines with the aid of power in premises within Jalalabad town area since 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: Asa Ram appellant runs certain machines with the aid of power in premises which are in a locality which is admittedly within the Jalalabad town area since the year 1953-54.

facts.text: District Board revision dismissed by Additional District Magistrate Judicial, Muzaffarnagar on July 13, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: There was a revision application by the District Board, which was dismissed by the Additional District Magistrate  Judicial , Muzaffarnagar, who agreed with the view of the Magistrate.

facts.text: District Board filed revision in Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The District Board then went up in revision to the High Court of Allahabad.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court single judge set aside acquittal and ordered retrial on May 11, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: He, therefore, set aside the acquittal and ordered a retrial. He also gave leave to appeal to this Court.

issues.text: Does s. 93(3) of the District Boards Act amount to a divestment of authority of the District Board in favour of the Town Area Committee?

anchor.surface_text: and Does s. 93 3  of the District Boards Act amount to a divestment of authority of the District Board in favour of the Town Area Committee ?

issues.text: Whether the bye-laws framed by the District Board under s.174(1)(k) read with s.106 apply to premises within the town area?

anchor.surface_text: This appeal on a certificate granted by the Allahabad High Court raises a question relating to the interpretation of certain provisions of the U. P. District Boards Act,  U. P. X of 1922 , and the U. P. Town Areas Act  U. P. No. II of 1914 .

issues.text: What happens when two statutory bodies have concurrent power in the same field?

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to the third question, namely, what happens when two statutory bodies have concurrent power in the same field?

arguments.claim: Bye-laws framed by District Board under s.174(1)(k) r/w s.106 do not apply to premises in Jalalabad town area; no licence required.

arguments.claim: s.93(3) does not divest District Board power post-1934 as it mentions 'town panchayat' not amended when Town Areas Act changed to 'Town Area Committee'; DB regains power after amendment.

anchor.surface_text: The argument of the learned Solicitor General in this behalf is that the District Board will be divested of its power to frame bye- laws for regulating offensive trades and callings in town areas, if the same authority is vested in the town panchayat. He goes on that now there are no Town Panchayats having authority in town areas,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t, as the case may be. There are certain exceptions to this provision, but we are number companycerned with them in the present case. The argument of

arguments.court_reasoning: Technical argument; mere formal name change/translation, no substantive change.

arguments.claim: Power of regulation under s.174(1)(k) District Boards Act and s.26(a) Town Areas Act includes issuing licences; s.106 only for fees where authorised elsewhere; distinguishes Mohamad Yasin (fees only).

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious therefore that s. 26 a  of the Town Areas Act is co-extensive with s. 174 1   k  of the District Boards Act, so far as regulation of offensive trades or callings is concerned. ... The High Court with respect seems to have mis- understood Mohamad Yasins case . That case turned on the question whether the Town Areas Committee could impose a fee

arguments.claim: 1934 amendment substituting 'Committee' for 'Panchayat' in Town Areas Act is mere formal change to avoid confusion with Village Panchayats; s.93(3) restriction continues; distinguishes Hira Devi.

anchor.surface_text: We must say that this is a very technical argument. The Town Areas Act was passed in 1914 and in the Act as it was originally passed the authority conferred by s. 26 a  was vested in the Town Panchayat. In 1920 the U. P. Village Panchayat Act was passed creating panchayats for any village or groups of villages.

arguments.claim: Law for smaller carved-out area (Town Areas Act) prevails over law for larger area (District Boards Act) when conflict; later/special prevails; cites English precedents (King v. Justices; Daw v. Metropolitan).

anchor.surface_text: The U. P. District Boards Act deals with a larger area in which the area constituting the town area is also included. The Town Areas Act on the other hand deals with a smaller area and on principle when there is a body dealing with a larger area and from that area is carved out a smaller area which is entrusted to another body,

holdings.text: The trades in question carried on by Asa Ram with his machines with the aid of power are offensive trades within s. 26(a) of the Town Areas Act and s. 174(1)(k) of the District Boards Act.

anchor.surface_text: As the learned Solicitor General does not contest the finding of the High Court that the trades in question carried on by Asa Ram with his machines with the aid of power are offensive trades, it follows that the Town Area Committee has power to regulate these trades as well as the District Board.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Solicitor-General does not contest High Court finding; provisions of s.26(a) and s.174(1)(k) are co-extensive for regulation of offensive trades.

holdings.text: Regulation under s. 26(a) of the Town Areas Act includes the power of issuing a licence.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the second point is concerned, the learned Solicitor General concedes that regulation would include the power of issuing a licence-and very rightly so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conceded by Solicitor-General; no specific licensing provision needed as regulation encompasses it; s.106 only for fees; distinguishes Mohamad Yasin case as concerning fees not licensing.

holdings.text: The Town Area Committee has power to frame bye-laws requiring licences for offensive trades under s. 26(a), same as District Board under s. 174(1)(k).

anchor.surface_text: The Town Area Committee would thus have the power to frame bye-laws requiring taking out of licences in case it exercises its power of regulation under s. 26 a  of the Town Areas Act in the same way as a District Board has the power of framing bye-laws under s. 174 1  k  requiring those carrying on certain trades to take out licences.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from regulation including licensing; District Boards Act lacks specific licensing but frames bye-laws under regulation power; s.106 merely enables fees where authorised.

holdings.text: s. 93(3) of the District Boards Act divests the District Board of authority in town areas vested in the town panchayat or committee; 1934 amendment substituting 'Committee' for 'Panchayat' effects no substantive change.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, when the word committee was substituted in place of panchayat in the Town Areas Act there was really no change of substance and the restriction on the power of the District Board under s. 93  3  of the District Boards Act to deal with matters entrusted to the town areas continued in full force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment was formal to avoid confusion with Village Panchayats; 'committee' is translation of 'panchayat'; rejects technical argument of lapse due to non-amendment.

holdings.text: s. 106 of the District Boards Act provides only for levying fees for licences authorised elsewhere, not authority to issue licences itself.

anchor.surface_text: Section 174 1   k  itself speaks only of regulating offensive trades, etc., and has not given in so many words power to issue licences. It is true that s. 106 provides that the board may charge a fee to be fixed by bye-law for any licence, sanction or permission which it is entitled or required to grant by or under the Act but that section merely provides for levying of fee where a licence is necessary under other provisions of the Act and is not in itself an authority for issue of licences.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading distinguishes licensing power (from regulation) from fee-levying power.

holdings.text: In case of concurrent powers between body governing larger area (District Board) and smaller carved-out area (Town Area Committee), the law empowering the smaller area body prevails.

anchor.surface_text: the law giving power to the body governing the smaller area should prevail over the law giving power to the body governing the larger area.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle from English precedents (King v. Justices of Middlesex; Daw v. Metropolitan Board); lex specialis derogat legi generali; applies even if 1934 creates new body.

holdings.text: The bye-laws framed by the District Board under s. 174(1)(k) read with s. 106 do not apply to premises within the town area.

anchor.surface_text: the power of the Town Area Committee must prevail over the power of the District Board under s. 174  1  k  of the District Boards Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.93(3) divests DB authority; alternatively, Town Areas Act (smaller area) prevails over District Boards Act (larger area).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court with respect seems to have mis- understood Mohamad Yasins case 1 . That case turned on the question whether the Town Areas Committee could impose a fee and did number deal with the question whether it could issue a licence.

precedents.cited_holding: no provision authorising Town Area Committee to levy licence-fee

precedents.cited_proposition: legislative lacuna cannot be supplied by liberal construction of statutes

precedents.cited_proposition: when two repugnant Acts passed in same session come into operation same day, the one with later Royal assent prevails
precedents.cited_holding: that which last received the Royal assent must prevail and be considered pro tanto a repeal of the other

anchor.surface_text: Again in Daw, Clerk of the Commissioner of Sewers of the City of London v. The Metropolitan Board of Works it was held- Where two statutes give authority to two public bodies to exercise powers which cannot companysistently with the object of the Legislature companyexist, the earlier must necessarily be repealed by the later statute.

precedents.case_name: Daw Clerk of the Commissioner of Sewers of the City of London v Metropolitan Board of Works
precedents.cited_proposition: later statute prevails over earlier when two statutes give concurrent powers to public bodies that cannot co-exist
precedents.cited_holding: the earlier must necessarily be repealed by the later statute

The later statute prevails doctrine supports the holding that the 1934 amendment to s. 93(3) divests authority from the District Board to the Town Area Committee as a later provision.
The doctrine supports the holding that in concurrent powers, the law empowering the smaller carved-out area body prevails over the larger area body, as the former is typically later.
The later statute prevails doctrine addresses whether s. 93(3) divests District Board authority in favor of Town Area Committee via later legislative change.
The doctrine directly addresses resolution of concurrent powers between statutory bodies by later statute prevailing if repugnant.

The Town Area Committee would thus have the power to frame bye-laws requiring taking out of licences in case it exercises its power of regulation under s. 26 a  of the Town Areas Act in the same way as a District Board has the power of framing bye-laws under s. 174 1  k  requiring those carrying on certain trades to take out licences.

edges.explanation: Holding states 's. 93(3) of the District Boards Act divests the District Board of authority in town areas vested in the town panchayat or committee', directly addressing the issue 'Does s. 93(3) ... amount to a divestment of authority of the District Board'.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, when the word committee was substituted in place of panchayat in the Town Areas Act there was really no change of substance and the restriction on the power of the District Board under s. 93  3  of the District Boards Act to deal with matters entrusted to the town areas continued in full force.

Therefore, when the word committee was substituted in place of panchayat in the Town Areas Act there was really no change of substance and the restriction on the power of the District Board under s. 93  3  of the District Boards Act to deal with matters entrusted to the town areas continued in full force.

Section 174 1   k  itself speaks only of regulating offensive trades, etc., and has not given in so many words power to issue licences. It is true that s. 106 provides that the board may charge a fee to be fixed by bye-law for any licence, sanction or permission which it is entitled or required to grant by or under the Act but that section merely provides for levying of fee where a licence is necessary under other provisions of the Act and is not in itself an authority for issue of licences.
